title: In Student Loan Reduction Attempt, the Department of Education Closes College Ranking
content:
NEW YORK ( MainStreet ) — The White House on Saturday officially shut down its two year effort to create a college ranking system , an idea opposed from the get-go by university presidents, school administrators and many elected officials, both Democrats and Republicans. 
 
President Obama's imprimatur was on the plan as he promoted it during a summer bus tour across New York State in 2013, but the  White House appeared to yield to critics who thought that a one-size-fits-all system wouldn't work for a group of this size. According to a federal study released this month, there were about 20 million students enrolled in 20 4,724 degree-granting institutions in 2013. 
 
A goal was to rank schools according to how much students borrowed and what their job prospects were when they left. In the process, the rankings would shame schools at the bottom into improving the product. 
 
This time around college ranking is being replaced with the new College Scorecard and will provide data that enables people to do some informed comparison shopping when looking for a college or university. The result was an unprecedented release of new federal data on loan repayment and post-college outcomes. 
 
“Americans will now have access to reliable data on every institution of higher education,” Obama said in his weekly address on September 12. “You’ll be able to see how much each school’s graduates earn, how much debt they graduate with and what percentage of a school’s students can pay back their loans – which will help all of us see which schools do the best job of preparing America for success.”
